body: Oh, I now see ipython/nbconvert#123 which might be related.
Yeah, a lot of people (the majority of the users) needs to show a lot of content in the same slide, so I decided to add the scrollbar by default to aid them.

Wouldn't subslide be a more appropriate solution? The problem I have now (on v1.1.0) is that the scrollbar is always there, even though there are no overflowing slides.

Regarding the wish to show a lot: shouldn't this be done via the css (reducing margins, etc)?

@akhmerov you can easily add a `custom.css` file with all your needs at the same folder where your slides.html file lives... and it will be applied... you can see the details here: http://www.damian.oquanta.info/posts/customizing-your-ipython-slides.html
We have to ship a default config suited to the mayority of users... hope it helps ;-)

Right, I know that I can add my own css. I don't understand why a scrollbar helps in a presentation though. As far as I know there is no single presentation software which allows to make a slide larger than a screen (including the reveal.js itself), so I would think that majority of users would rather want their slides to fit a single screen.

scrollbar have been added mainly when you have the output of a cell which is longer than the screen. 
for example tracebacks, `!pip install whatever` and so on... Then you do not have the control of what is overflowing and you cannot make this into multiple subslides. So it is not that user do **want** scroll bar. it is just that in some cases you kind of need them. 

I for example have been many time annoyed by the need to zoom-in, and then my slides where off the screen, and un readable because I couln't scroll.

I think that scrolling in a presentation is not a good idea, and other methods are generally preferable. The reason I think so is the following. 

In a presentation many people need to access visual information, and they do it with different speeds. What's bad for them is that they are going to access the information using the timing that you are imposing. If someone forgot what was the input of your long ipython cell, and wants to look it up by the time you scrolled down, you've essentially lost that person. Also scrolling doesn't split the text into logical segments, instead truncating it arbitrarily: the viewer basically stops halfway through

whatever you wanted them to read :-)

Overall I think, that presentation format is/should be rather restricted, and not every ipython notebook is suitable to make a presentation out of it. If one wants to make the presentation, I think that having a scrollbar would be almost universally a suboptimal decision to e.g. scaling each slide, or somehow breaking the output into several subslides.

> Overall I think, that presentation format is/should be rather restricted, and not every ipython notebook is suitable to make a presentation out of it.

Probably a lot of user disagree with that opinion... They (and I) want to get slides from their working ipynb with the minimal effort... and they have to do a lot of things right now because we had to achieve an equilibrium point between automatically generated slides and versatility to change structural things accordingly with their needs...

> I think that having a scrollbar would be almost universally a suboptimal decision to e.g. scaling each slide, or somehow breaking the output into several subslides.

I disagree with you here... I mean, you reasons are very valuable and logical, but... the IPython slides are not a typical presentation framework... they are derived from IPython notebook, so I think we have to change some "rules" to better fit the notebook scope, and this is the reason I think the scrollbar is a more robust solution at this stage...

> Probably a lot of user disagree with that opinion... They (and I) want to get slides from their 
> working ipynb with the minimal effort...
> 
>  the IPython slides are not a typical presentation framework... they are derived from IPython notebook

I agree with you (and the majority of IPython nbconvert reveal users) that one doesn't want to pay a lot of effort in modifying a notebook in order to make it suitable for a presentation. However if you don't want to be bothered paying effort, there's nbviewer and nbconvert html. Both use way less effort than required by preparing the presentation (no need to work with the cell metadata), and if you want just a refreshed look, then a custom css will work wonders in the latter case. Then you get something that you can just likewise show in the browser, and navigate via scrolling.

The "rules" which you want to change for the "special case of IPython notebook" aren't imposed by anyone, this is just what you need to do to make an OK presentation. If making an OK presentation is not the idea, I would like to know what is the actual intended use of the converter to reveal.js.

Granted the above, I can absolutely see how one can make use of a quick-and-dirty presentation, where long outputs are used. What I tried to explain above was that even in that case scrolling is inferior to e.g. automatic scaling of the slides content, or scrolling long output just like done within ipython notebook itself.

As a final remark, I would like to also say that the current solution is in a way not Pythonic. We all enjoy Python for its emphasis on the ease of understanding the code. I think that the following statements from 'The Zen of Python' apply to our dispute:

> Simple is better than complex.
> Sparse is better than dense.
> Readability counts.

> I agree with you (and the majority of IPython nbconvert reveal users) that one doesn't want to pay a lot of effort in modifying a notebook in order to make it suitable for a presentation. 

Great!

> However if you don't want to be bothered paying effort, there's nbviewer and nbconvert html.

If the payment is too much high, probably nobody will use this slideshow format, so I think we have to keep the payment as lower as we can... whereas we achieve all the "necessary" features of a good slideshow framework.

> The "rules" which you want to change for the "special case of IPython notebook" aren't imposed by anyone, this is just what you need to do to make an OK presentation. If making an OK presentation is not the idea, I would like to know what is the actual intended use of the converter to reveal.js.

I agree with you... we just think different about what is an OK presentation in the current stage (which is not the broad stage of a more general presentation framework).

> Granted the above, I can absolutely see how one can make use of a quick-and-dirty presentation, where long outputs are used. What I tried to explain above was that even in that case scrolling is inferior to e.g. automatic scaling of the slides content, or scrolling long output just like done within ipython notebook itself.

I don't think that scrolling is inferior to automatic scaling of the slides... but at the end is a subjective opinion...
Suppose you have automatic scaled slides, probably you can reorder your content making this scaled slides as subslides... in a not automated way (I know)... but you achieve the same result... btw, the implementation of the automatic scaling would not be trivial... because if would be difficult to not cut the content in an inappropriate way... 
About the scrolling long outputs as the IPython notebook itself... it is an interesting point to further investigate ;-)

> As a final remark, I would like to also say that the current solution is in a way not Pythonic. We all enjoy Python for its emphasis on the ease of understanding the code. I think that the following statements from 'The Zen of Python' apply to our dispute:

I think that the automatic scaling is the not Pythonic way, nor simpler than scrolling... but again, it is a subjective matter ;-)
I really appreciate your comments... and you have valid points here, just I think the scrolling is a better solution right now to solve the problem.

> we just think different about what is an OK presentation in the current stage 
> (which is not the broad stage of a more general presentation framework).

Then please explain why the idea that the viewers should be able to easily follow the presentation content does not apply. Also I would like to know why `ipython nbconvert --to html` is not an OK presentation already.

> I don't think that scrolling is inferior to automatic scaling of the slides... but at the end is a subjective opinion...

No it isn't a subjective opinion. We're discussing an implementation of a technology with a set aim (delivering information to large audience), and not whether it looks pretty. I explained above why scrolling is harder to follow by many people at once (breaks of content that don't match the logic, and impossibility to return to the previous part of the same logical segment (slide) once it was scrolled away). How is that a subjective opinion?

By the way, another complication that you are forgetting is that while presentations with scrolling are easier to generate, they mean that you cannot give the presentation using a remote, and you have to stick next to the laptop when giving the presentation (most remotes only have forward/backward button). Majority of the speakers that I encounter past the PhD level (which simply means that they are giving presentations more frequently) use the remote. So yeah, it takes little effort to make a presentation, but it takes appreciably more effort to deliver the talk.

> I think that the automatic scaling is the not Pythonic way, nor simpler than scrolling... but again, it is a subjective matter ;-)

Well, once again, we're not talking about what 'looks good', but rather about what is easier to read, so it's less so subjective. I still didn't hear your explanation how scrolled slides are easier to read than slides that are fully on a single screen. Of course (and I also stated it before), short and simple slides are even easier to read than ones with lengthy output.

> and you have valid points here, just I think the scrolling is a better solution right now

I already understood that that is your current opinion. What I do not understand is the reasoning behind it, so I would be grateful if you explain your motivation in more detail.

# 

However our discussion is by now too abstract, so to be more specific I have modified the slides from the presentation I gave yesterday to actually overflow (I simply merged two consequtive slides), see http://antonakhmerov.org/scrolling_presentation.png

Of course, I have organised my talk such that these were two slides. So first of all you see that in this case a scrollbar isn't even necessary, because there's an elephantine gap at the top of the slide, and two of its sisters at the sides. Second, this illustrated rather clearly that until I finish talking about the first image, which probably take me around 3-5 minutes, there will be an unknown broken bit of stuff at the bottom, which nobody can understand. Imagine that just removing the gap from the top wouldn't solve the problem, and the slide would still end in half an image. Do you still think that this is better than the case when all of the slide is scaled to 90%?

If there was no ipython/nbconvert#123 (which I had as well), even the css modification wouldn't be necessary.

Unrelated to my discussion with @damianavila, the original issue is still a bug for the following reason. Assuming that the scrollbar is what one wants, the fact that it disappears once the browser is made narrow is a bug: the need to scroll doesn't disappear.

> Then please explain why the idea that the viewers should be able to easily follow the presentation content does not apply. 

Obviously, the viewers should be able to easily follow the presentation... Just, I think that, taking in to account the nature of the notebook (I mean, the cells and their variable output), the scrolling approach is the best compromise between a working solution and and the cost associated to develop a more strong solution. 

> Also I would like to know why ipython nbconvert --to html is not an OK presentation already.

It is an OK presentation for a lot of people... I think that the slides are better, but at the end is a question of taste.

> No it isn't a subjective opinion. We're discussing an implementation of a technology with a set aim (delivering information to large audience), and not whether it looks pretty. I explained above why scrolling is harder to follow by many people at once (breaks of content that don't match the logic, and impossibility to return to the previous part of the same logical segment (slide) once it was scrolled away). How is that a subjective opinion?

Scrolling can be difficult to follow for some people, but the same goes for auto scaling slides... because you break your content... I conceived the slide as the minimal unit of information in the presentation... so the content from one slide should not be splitted in child slides... but again, this is my opinion, others can disagree.

> By the way, another complication that you are forgetting is that while presentations with scrolling are easier to generate, they mean that you cannot give the presentation using a remote, and you have to stick next to the laptop when giving the presentation (most remotes only have forward/backward button). Majority of the speakers that I encounter past the PhD level (which simply means that they are giving presentations more frequently) use the remote. So yeah, it takes little effort to make a presentation, but it takes appreciably more effort to deliver the talk.

You could configure your remote to make the scrolling... but if you do not want scroll, just reorder your content to fit the no-scrolling slides approach.

> Well, once again, we're not talking about what 'looks good', but rather about what is easier to read, so it's less so subjective. I still didn't hear your explanation how scrolled slides are easier to read than slides that are fully on a single screen. Of course (and I also stated it before), short and simple slides are even easier to read than ones with lengthy output.

But... you are forgetting about the nature of IPython cells... they can be very large... not only the output cells, the input cells too... and the framework is cell-dependant, so if you have an input cell bigger than the single screen, you will need an scrolling element and this can happens very frequently, ie. if you are using larger fonts than the default ones (which improves readibility) And the same goes to the output. OK, you can say "scroll inside the cells" and it would be possible, but I think it would be very difficult to read for viewers...

> I already understood that that is your current opinion. What I do not understand is the reasoning behind it, so I would be grateful if you explain your motivation in more detail.

I think I gave you one idea of the reasoning in the last lines...

> However our discussion is by now too abstract, so to be more specific I have modified the slides from the presentation I gave yesterday to actually overflow (I simply merged two consequtive slides), see http://antonakhmerov.org/scrolling_presentation.png
> Of course, I have organised my talk such that these were two slides. So first of all you see that in this case a scrollbar isn't even necessary, because there's an elephantine gap at the top of the slide, and two of its sisters at the sides. 

How the elements are arranged in the slides is organized by reveal.js, we can not easily modify this organization without dealing a lot with the reveal source code, and this is out of my scope.
In the case you show me, I would probably use larger fonts to minimize the gap, and split the content in two slides...

> Second, this illustrated rather clearly that until I finish talking about the first image, which probably take me around 3-5 minutes, there will be an unknown broken bit of stuff at the bottom, which nobody can understand. Imagine that just removing the gap from the top wouldn't solve the problem, and the slide would still end in half an image. Do you still think that this is better than the case when all of the slide is scaled to 90%?

Finally, the implementation of auto scales slides is not trivial, and I think it does not worth the cost...
But, if you think it worths... you can submit a PR with a working implementation, so we can evaluate the benefits of this new approach compare with the current one and decide if is suitable for merging...

> Unrelated to my discussion with @damianavila, the original issue is still a bug for the following reason. Assuming that the scrollbar is what one wants, the fact that it disappears once the browser is made narrow is a bug: the need to scroll doesn't disappear.

I submitted a PR #4322 that solves (in a cost effective way) the desappear of the scrolling bar when you narrow the browser window (if you narrow too much, which is **no sense** for present your content, obviously it desappears, but a complete solution probably needs an overall rewrite of the reveal.css, and I think this is again out of the scope)..
@damianavila what is the status of this?

Taking into account this one:

> As far as I'm concerned, this bug report can be closed since I'm (and already was) satisfied with @damianavila's argument.

I think we can close it.
